entry.value: This page features nested logic statements in Rapid.

In Rapid it is possible, and uncommon, to wrap multiple logic statements together based on success and fail logic. On this page we will give some examples on how to go about nesting logic statements in various ways. Nesting logic statements can be especially useful when using Rapid mobile apps, as an unsuccessful result can check the internet connection and then display results or pages as necessary.

As a simple example of what can be done with nested logic statements the below example will change the colour of the input box based on which checkboxes are checked. Whilst a simple example, it is a good benchmark to get the experimenting gloves on, and is a good way to introduce the concept.

With a simple example covered we are now going to move onto something slightly more usable. This next example will cover showing and hiding panels and buttons in relation to information provided from a user.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"

// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"

Are you interested in getting in contact with us?
Please send us your email address
alert("Email successfully logged. Thank you for your interest in Rapid!");
Please do get in touch if you have an queries or questions about Rapid!
Have you seen what Rapid has to offer?
alert("Email successfully logged. Thank you for your interest in Rapid!");
Please have a look at our website for more details!

In our final example we will be using nested logic to display different pages as a dialogue, based on the answers given in the following questions. This way of displaying dialogues can be useful if you are making a form application and wish to have different progression routes based on what is entered. There are, of course, multiple ways of doing this within Rapid and this is a simple example on how to do so.
Rapid offers a drag and drop designer
All created apps can have a unique style and feel

[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P11_C58_","text":"Whilst simple, this example is a good stepping stone into nested logic
actions. Logic actions by themselves offer a variety of different options,
being able to assign values and options if something is true or/and false.
Multiple conditions can be mapped against, and when doing so you gain the
option to open or close the success or fail actions further using And and Or.
And is used to be restrictive, and Or is used to be more open.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P11_C171_","text":"Based on the answers provided users will see different sets of panels with more questions, with
each change in option clearing the entered data of the other. If seen in the Rapid designer it
is evident that the logic and actions behind this example are not as simple as one would think.
There are a lot of checks at work, and in order to perform seamlessly there is logic present to
remove previous content if options are changed.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P11_C315_","text":"The example provided here has a much easier understanding in terms of it's background mechanics in comparison to
the previous example. Whilst simpler, this example is also likely to be used slightly less, or in a different
manner. With Rapid there is a lot of flexibility in terms of how different actions and events can be carried out,
and the way in which each control flows with one another is also very different. For example, this nested logic
can easily be done in a non-nested manner, however for the purposes of this page we are using nested logic.","type":"hover"}]

{"controlHints":[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P11_C58_","text":"Whilst simple, this example is a good stepping stone into nested logic
actions. Logic actions by themselves offer a variety of different options,
being able to assign values and options if something is true or/and false.
Multiple conditions can be mapped against, and when doing so you gain the
option to open or close the success or fail actions further using And and Or.
And is used to be restrictive, and Or is used to be more open.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P11_C171_","text":"Based on the answers provided users will see different sets of panels with more questions, with
each change in option clearing the entered data of the other. If seen in the Rapid designer it
is evident that the logic and actions behind this example are not as simple as one would think.
There are a lot of checks at work, and in order to perform seamlessly there is logic present to
remove previous content if options are changed.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P11_C315_","text":"The example provided here has a much easier understanding in terms of it's background mechanics in comparison to
the previous example. Whilst simpler, this example is also likely to be used slightly less, or in a different
manner. With Rapid there is a lot of flexibility in terms of how different actions and events can be carried out,
and the way in which each control flows with one another is also very different. For example, this nested logic
can easily be done in a non-nested manner, however for the purposes of this page we are using nested logic.","type":"hover"}]}

page.htmlBody:
This page features nested logic statements in Rapid.

In Rapid it is possible, and uncommon, to wrap multiple logic statements together based on success and fail logic. On this page we will give some examples on how to go about nesting logic statements in various ways. Nesting logic statements can be especially useful when using Rapid mobile apps, as an unsuccessful result can check the internet connection and then display results or pages as necessary.As a simple example of what can be done with nested logic statements the below example will change the colour of the input box based on which checkboxes are checked. Whilst a simple example, it is a good benchmark to get the experimenting gloves on, and is a good way to introduce the concept.
Change colour
With a simple example covered we are now going to move onto something slightly more usable. This next example will cover showing and hiding panels and buttons in relation to information provided from a user.
Are you interested in Rapid?
Are you interested in getting in contact with us?
Please send us your email address
Please do get in touch if you have an queries or questions about Rapid!
Have you seen what Rapid has to offer?
Please send us your thoughts
Please have a look at our website for more details!
In our final example we will be using nested logic to display different pages as a dialogue, based on the answers given in the following questions. This way of displaying dialogues can be useful if you are making a form application and wish to have different progression routes based on what is entered. There are, of course, multiple ways of doing this within Rapid and this is a simple example on how to do so.
Rapid offers a drag and drop designer
Rapid is completely open source
All created apps can have a unique style and feel
page.name: 15_nestedLogic

rolesHtml.html:
This page features nested logic statements in Rapid.

In Rapid it is possible, and uncommon, to wrap multiple logic statements together based on success and fail logic. On this page we will give some examples on how to go about nesting logic statements in various ways. Nesting logic statements can be especially useful when using Rapid mobile apps, as an unsuccessful result can check the internet connection and then display results or pages as necessary.As a simple example of what can be done with nested logic statements the below example will change the colour of the input box based on which checkboxes are checked. Whilst a simple example, it is a good benchmark to get the experimenting gloves on, and is a good way to introduce the concept.
Change colour
With a simple example covered we are now going to move onto something slightly more usable. This next example will cover showing and hiding panels and buttons in relation to information provided from a user.

In our final example we will be using nested logic to display different pages as a dialogue, based on the answers given in the following questions. This way of displaying dialogues can be useful if you are making a form application and wish to have different progression routes based on what is entered. There are, of course, multiple ways of doing this within Rapid and this is a simple example on how to do so.

All created apps can have a unique style and feel

page.title: Nested logic statements
